content:
In the category Top\bf TopTop of Grothendieck toposes and geometric morphisms there are two well-known factorisation systems:

  • the (hyperconnected,localic) factorisation scheme,
  • the (surjection,embedding) factorisation scheme.

The former is well-behaved with pullbacks. For example, localic geometric morphisms are stable under pullback - i.e. given a pullback diagram

E×GF→fE↓↓F→gG\begin{CD} \mathcal{E} \times_{\mathcal{G}} \mathcal{F} @>{f}>> \mathcal{E}\\ @VVV @VVV\\ \mathcal{F} @>{g}>>\mathcal{G} \end{CD}E×G​F↓⏐​F​f​g​​E↓⏐​G​

in which ggg is localic, then so too is fff. Inclusions are also preserved under pullback (see Example A4.5.14(e) of the Elephant). The same is not true for surjections. However, we do have that open surjections are stable under pullback.

Let TopWP\bf TopWPTopWP denote the full subcategory of Top\bf TopTop of Grothendieck toposes with enough points (a topos E\mathcal{E}E has enough points if there exists a set XXX and a geometric surjection SetsX→E{\bf Sets}^X \to \mathcal{E}SetsX→E). The category TopWP\bf TopWPTopWP clearly inherits both factorisation schemes from Top\bf TopTop. Let E→F\mathcal{E} \to \mathcal{F}E→F be a geometric morphism between two toposes with enough points, and let

E→hypE′→locF\begin{CD} \mathcal{E} @>{hyp}>> \mathcal{E}' @>{loc}>> \mathcal{F} \end{CD}Ehyp​E′loc​F

be the (hyperconnected,localic) factorisation in Top\bf TopTop. As hyperconnected morphisms are surjections, there exists a surjection SetsX→E→hypE′{\bf Sets}^X \to \mathcal{E} \xrightarrow{hyp} \mathcal{E}'SetsX→Ehyp​E′. The (surjection,embedding) case is identical.

So the natural next question is whether we obtain similar pullback stability properties in TopWP\bf TopWPTopWP. We know, by Corollary 7.18 in Johnstone's Topos theory, that for each topos E\mathcal{E}E there exists a unique largest subtopos Pt(E){\rm Pt}(\mathcal{E})Pt(E) that has enough points. Thus, for each geometric morphism F→fE\mathcal{F} \xrightarrow{f} \mathcal{E}Ff​E where F\mathcal{F}F has enough points, fff factors through the subtopos Pt(E){\rm Pt}(\mathcal{E})Pt(E). Therefore the pullback in TopWP\bf TopWPTopWP of a pair of arrows

E⟶G⟵F\mathcal{E} \longrightarrow \mathcal{G} \longleftarrow \mathcal{F}E⟶G⟵F

is given by Pt(E×GF){\rm Pt}(\mathcal{E} \times_{\mathcal{G}} \mathcal{F})Pt(E×G​F), where E×GF\mathcal{E} \times_{\mathcal{G}} \mathcal{F}E×G​F is the pullback in Top\bf TopTop. As Pt(E×GF){\rm Pt}(\mathcal{E} \times_{\mathcal{G}} \mathcal{F})Pt(E×G​F) is a subtopos of E×GF\mathcal{E} \times_{\mathcal{G}} \mathcal{F}E×G​F, and inclusions are localic, it immediately follows that localic geometric morphisms and geometric embeddings are stable under pullback in TopWP\bf TopWPTopWP.

My question to the forum is this: is there an easy way to see whether or not

  • hyperconnected morphisms and
  • open surjections

are also stable under pullback in TopWP\bf TopWPTopWP? In the lack of an easy way, is there a hard way?

@Ivan Di Liberti and I are working on understanding which toposes have enough points with enough clarity to answer that kind of question, although I have been distracted enough by other things that the progress has been very slow lately.

I expect there to be counterexamples to at least the second bullet point. A potential strategy would be to exploit the following two observations:

  1. while the codomain of a surjection from a topos with enough points necessarily has enough points, not all of its points need factor through the surjection.
  2. A point of the pullback is a pair of points which complete the square defining the pullback.

I reckon that with a clever gluing of two toposes you could construct a pullback of a surjection whose subtopos with enough points is the degenerate subtopos.
iirc a hyperconnected morphism which is not surjective on points appears in one of @Jens Hemelaer 's papers, maybe he can remind me which one.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

iirc a hyperconnected morphism which is not surjective on points appears in one of Jens Hemelaer 's papers, maybe he can remind me which one.

Yes, there's an example at the end of Subsection 3.1 in "A topological groupoid representing the topos of presheaves on a monoid". As pointed out by the reviewer, it is not the first example. There's also an example in the Elephant, Example D3.4.14, of an atomic topos that is hyperconnected (over Sets\mathbf{Sets}Sets) and does not have any points.

The example from my paper goes more or less like this:
Take a cardinal α\alphaα and let M1M_1M1​ and M2M_2M2​ be the free monoid on α\alphaα generators and the free commutative monoid on α\alphaα generators, respectively. The projection map M1→M2M_1 \to M_2M1​→M2​ induces a hyperconnected, essential geometric morphism at the level of presheaf toposes. As soon as α\alphaα is big enough (e.g. α=∣R∣\alpha=|\mathbb{R}|α=∣R∣), then this geometric morphism is not surjective on points.

For any hyperconnected geometric morphism f:F→Ef : \mathcal{F} \to \mathcal{E}f:F→E that is not surjective on points, you can take a point p:Sets→Ep : \mathbf{Sets} \to \mathcal{E}p:Sets→E that is not in the pointwise image of fff. The pullback of fff along ppp in TopWP\mathbf{TopWP}TopWP is then the inclusion of the empty topos in Sets\mathbf{Sets}Sets, and this is not surjective anymore. So hyperconnected geometric morphisms and open surjections both fail to be stable under pullback in TopWP\mathbf{TopWP}TopWP.
Thanks @Morgan Rogers (he/him) for writing out the strategy!

Aha so the clever gluing isn't even necessary! iirc the example in the Elephant is unbounded over sets (since every bounded connected atomic topos has a point by a result in C3.5), and in any case using a topos with no points wouldn't give a counterexample here, so your example is really necessary :wink:

The example in the Elephant is bounded over Sets\mathbf{Sets}Sets (there are easier unbounded examples as well). Maybe the result from C3.5 you are thinking of is that every connected atomic topos with a point is bounded?
Thanks @Jens Hemelaer @Morgan Rogers (he/him) for the counter example!

Jens Hemelaer said:

The example in the Elephant is bounded over Sets\mathbf{Sets}Sets (there are easier unbounded examples as well). Maybe the result from C3.5 you are thinking of is that every connected atomic topos with a point is bounded?

Ah yep, that's what I was thinking of. I did not recall correctly!
